question: Which motion of the Earth causes the day–night cycle?

content.source_1: Earth is a planet that spins on its axis approximately once every 24 hours.
content.source_2: Earth’s rotation axis is tilted about 23.5 degrees relative to the perpendicular to the plane of its orbit around the Sun.
content.source_3: At any given moment, half of Earth’s surface is illuminated by the Sun while the opposite half is in darkness.
content.source_4: Inside the Arctic and Antarctic Circles, there are extended periods each year of continuous daylight (midnight sun) and continuous darkness (polar night) because of Earth’s axial tilt.
content.source_5: The number of daylight hours at a given latitude changes throughout the year due to Earth’s axial tilt relative to its orbit.
content.source_6: Over the course of a year, Earth orbits the Sun once, and the hemisphere tilted toward the Sun receives more direct sunlight and longer days while the opposite hemisphere has shorter days.
